image.altText: Bob Hawke

items.synopsis: Bob Hawke returned from the remote Northern Territory in 1988 to a divided, partisan parliament. Some say this sunk the prospect of a treaty before the idea ever got off the ground.

title.children: In 1988, prime minister Bob Hawke promised a treaty with Aboriginal people. Why did it fail?

items.synopsis: How sneaker brands charge up to 10,000 times the cost of manufacturing — and fans eat it up.

title.children: 'Instant credibility': Why kids are spending thousands on 'virtual sneakers' they can't even wear

image.altText: Hunter Biden, dressed in a suit, is seen outside.

items.synopsis: Hunter Biden, the son of US President Joe Biden, is charged with three gun offences, setting him on course for a possible criminal trial as his father campaigns for re-election in 2024.

title.children: Hunter Biden charged with gun crimes after allegedly lying about his drug addiction

image.altText: Taylor Swift stands on stage holding microphone wearing black sparkly leotard with long sleeves.

items.synopsis: Despite a cost-of-living crisis, Australians are willing to spend more to see live music. And some celebrities are finding ways to encourage them.

title.children: 'Staggering' prices and new marketing ploys: How the economics of live music is changing

image.altText: A black-and-white shot of a middle-aged man in a dark hat and coat, bearing a grim expression.

items.synopsis: In 1951 an SA fisherman ventured out to cast a line into the flooding Murray River. The truth behind the profoundly disturbing discovery he made remains unknown to this day — but that may be about to change.

title.children: Push to solve cold case mystery of petrified woman found without a face, teeth, hands or feet

image.altText: A man in glasses

items.synopsis: Over three years, this Canadian man is alleged to have sent 1,200 self-poison kits to people in 40 countries around the world. Interpol says some of them have reached Australia.

title.children: How the alleged 'poison seller' of Canada may have sent his deadly kits into Australia

image.altText: Princess Diana wearing a red jumper with white and black sheep.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Princess Diana's iconic black sheep jumper sells for millions. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is holding a rural medical training summit in Canberra today in response to crippling rural workforce shortages and a lack of specialist training opportunities throughout regional Australia. AMA president Steve Robson told News Breakfast the state in the regions was "catastrophic". "Australians who live outside our capital cities understand how difficult it is to see a heart specialist, a psychiatrist, an obstetrician to have a baby," he told the program. "There are critical shortages. Australians who live in those regions can't wait any longer." Dr Robson says training will play a critical role in building a rural and regional workforce.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMA says regional health workforce shortages are 'catastrophic'

props.alt: A man in a suit jacket wearing glasses.

children.content: (ABC News)

The Australian Medical Association (AMA) is holding a rural medical training summit in Canberra today in response to crippling rural workforce shortages and a lack of specialist training opportunities throughout regional Australia.
AMA president Steve Robson told News Breakfast the state in the regions was "catastrophic".
"Australians who live outside our capital cities understand how difficult it is to see a heart specialist, a psychiatrist, an obstetrician to have a baby," he told the program.
"There are critical shortages. Australians who live in those regions can't wait any longer."
Dr Robson says training will play a critical role in building a rural and regional workforce.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A woman has died in hospital after police used a taser following a seige near Newcastle. Just after 12.30pm yesterday police were called to a unit in Stockton, following reports a woman was threatening people with an axe. On arrival, the 47-year-old woman allegedly threatened police with the axe before barricading herself inside a unit. Specialist tactical officers arrived including negotiators, before police gained entry about 9.45pm. Police used a taser along with a number of "tactical options" to take the woman into custody. She was then escorted from the scene to an ambulance, however, her condition deteriorated a short time later, and she was taken to John Hunter Hospital, where she later died. That investigation will be subject to an independent review. A report will be prepared for the information of the Coroner.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woman dies in hospital after being tasered by NSW police

featuredLink.title: Woman dies after being tasered by police at Stockton near Newcastle

children.content: A woman has died in hospital after police used a taser following a seige near Newcastle.
Just after 12.30pm yesterday police were called to a unit in Stockton, following reports a woman was threatening people with an axe.
On arrival, the 47-year-old woman allegedly threatened police with the axe before barricading herself inside a unit.
Specialist tactical officers arrived including negotiators, before police gained entry about 9.45pm.
Police used a taser along with a number of "tactical options" to take the woman into custody.
She was then escorted from the scene to an ambulance, however, her condition deteriorated a short time later, and she was taken to John Hunter Hospital, where she later died.
That investigation will be subject to an independent review.
A report will be prepared for the information of the Coroner.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Dozens of doctors and nurses silently lined the hospital hallway in tribute: For a history-making two months, a pig’s kidney worked normally inside the brain-dead man. The dramatic experiment came to an end Wednesday as surgeons at NYU Langone Health removed the pig kidney and returned the donated body of Maurice “Mo” Miller to his family for cremation. It marked the longest a genetically modified pig kidney has ever functioned inside a human, albeit a deceased one. And by pushing the boundaries of research with the dead, the scientists learned critical lessons they're preparing to share with the Food and Drug Administration — in hopes of eventually testing pig kidneys in the living. Reporting by AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pig kidney works a record two months in donated body

props.alt: Two women in scrubs standing next to a bed.

children.content: (AP: Shelby Lum)
Dozens of doctors and nurses silently lined the hospital hallway in tribute: For a history-making two months, a pig’s kidney worked normally inside the brain-dead man.
The dramatic experiment came to an end Wednesday as surgeons at NYU Langone Health removed the pig kidney and returned the donated body of Maurice “Mo” Miller to his family for cremation.
It marked the longest a genetically modified pig kidney has ever functioned inside a human, albeit a deceased one.

And by pushing the boundaries of research with the dead, the scientists learned critical lessons they're preparing to share with the Food and Drug Administration — in hopes of eventually testing pig kidneys in the living.
Reporting by AP

image.altText: A cruiseship is stuck in low water, two smaller boats have come up to it, a rugged hillside is in the background

image.altText: Marcia Langton at a press conference in Parliament House

items.synopsis: Bunburying is the art of concocting a noble-sounding alibi to provide cover for an undisclosed and less-noble objective. Why is this relevant today? Because senior First Nations academic Marcia Langton has been at the centre of a comprehensive Bunburying. Here's what transpired, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: There's a foul, rising tide of racism in the Voice debate ahead of the referendum

items.synopsis: As the death toll is expected to rise in Libya's disastrous floods, Derna has been hit harder than any other city. Here's how crumbling infrastructure and a decade of political chaos left the region reeling.

title.children: As many as 20,000 may have died. Why has the destruction of Derna's dams caused so much chaos?
